date: stated on May 27, 2019 in a Facebook post:
title: No, this bike is in a tree. It's not a memorial to a fallen soldier.
text: A bike in a tree on Fashon Island, Wash, is the objects of the fortune-teller, including the myth that continues around a boy who is no longer a war. "The least we forget," book May 27 Facebook begins. A boy went to war in 1914 and left his bike tied to a tree. He never came home and the family left the bike there as a souvenir to the soldier who fell." This article, which contains a picture of a red rusty bike that appears to grow from a tree, was highlighted as part of Facebook's efforts to combat false news and misleading information in the broadcast of the news. ∙ (Read more about our partnership with Facebook.) In 2009, the Vashon-Moury Island Bitskomber, a local publication in Vashon, an island about 15 minutes from Seattle, published a report on a long-standing family "proclaimed a strong bike demand." Don Bozz, who graduated from Fashun High School in 1963 and served as Deputy Chief of Police until he retired in 1991, said that the bike had been donated to him after he burned down his family home. He was too young for him, and he claims to have left him in 1954 in the woods, and he forgot about it and never came back for him. His mother told the newspaper that her son and his friends were playing in the woods and that Bozz was the only child on his bike there. When the boys left, he left his bike and walked home with them. After the bike was discovered and attracted the attention of the media, Boz visited the bike, saying Pitchchumber. "I knew him immediately." And when I saw that bike, I knew it, because I don't think I've seen another bike like it before." In 2013, Seattle News also spoke to Bozz, who said he didn't suspect his bike. He said, "It's a few hundred feet from my mom's house where I was playing in the woods."
